Posts.Title: liver clear! moonlight60 moonlight60

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2013 08:39PM - edited Jan 14, 2013 09:50PM by KeepingFaith69 Kia Ora e Kia orana, I live in New Zealand and am of Maori, Cook Island, Tahitian and Welsh decent. I was 40 at dx in 2010, and received the worst news on my 43rd birthday in December 2012 - possible mets. This was confirmed on the 31/12/12 and I started xeloda / tykerb on the 1/1/2013. I am currently a Systems Analyst for an insurance company, and am looking to try something different. The stage IV diagnosis has me thinking I want to do work that makes my heart sing, so I am considering a range of options that will have me contribute positively to the community I live in. I am married to my best friend and the love of my life. I am the proud mummy of two young men who fill my heart with joy every day. The older one was born in October 1998 and my baby was born in July 2005. I want to see them grow into men, I want to share with them their major milestones and I want to spoil their children. I have always lived a healthy lifestyle abd feel bitterly ripped off by cancer. Pae xo

Sending you prayers of ease.  Cancer stinks and the treatment isnt muich better, but it does pass.

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2013 03:49PM KeepingFaith69 wrote: Hi Silvie, Welcome and warm hugs to you. I am new to iv and am beginning to function normally. I was a hyper ventilating mess (on top of breathing / coughing issues) in December. It didn't help that I was also sleep deprived due to not bring able to lie down. I found the women on this forum helpful and genuinely caring. This has helped me find my way towards living again. It's taken me 5 weeks to add stage iv to my tag line, it still looks surreal. I was told that once I had a treatment plan, I would feel better. It's true! I started xeloda/tykerb on the 1/1/2013 and I feel better. I can breathe, the coughing is gone, the back pain has gone and I can sleep. More importantly, I feel better knowing that something is being done to rid my body of those awful lurgies. Wishing you well Pae xo

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2013 12:49AM KeepingFaith69 wrote: Hi Anastasia, The fear you feel is normal. It flipped me upside down, but I got past it. I was 40 when diagnosed with stage 0 and was diagnosed with stage iv the day before my 43rd birthday. It saddens me that I could miss out on the milestones of my darling children (7 and 14). I come to this site often for support and advice, get as informed as I can and avoid statistics on prognosis. I also draw on advice from my best friend, who is also my husband. While crying over the future (over which I have little control) I could be missing out on the precious now. So now I try live in the moment and be present to the treasures in front of me. Prayer helps me as well. Sending you gentle hugs Pae xo

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 10:57PM KeepingFaith69 wrote: Hi Ladies, Well, the "unwelcome visitor" was evicted from my chest on Tuesday 29/11.  Scans yesterday and now it's a waiting game (the waiting drives me craaaaaazy). Treated my mum and i to a manucure and pedicure the day beforehand.  Nearly cried when they had to remove the pretty red polish from my hand on Tuesday morning.  So we found a compromise.  They removed the polish from only one finger.  I am giggling as I type, looking at my perfectly manicured nails, with one finger au naturale'. Love and light to all : )
Posts.Title: December 2011 Surgeries - want to wait together? CookieMonster Moonflwr912

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 11:47PM - edited Nov 30, 2011 11:48PM by KeepingFaith69 My colleagues are beginning to show their true collours - selfish to the bone. I work hard to rediuce the impact that my absences have on their work load, and yet they still snicker and make snide comments about the time I am away. I wouldnt have anything of them walk in my shoes for minute. I managed to get myself all upset and feel like I had to justify my every move and it didnt change a thing. I changed tact and decided to be me.  Every day I wear my prettiest and brightest dress, and greet them with a smile and the sunniest 'good morning' I can muster.  They don't know what to do with that response.  Buying into their negativity gave them what they wanted, and dragged me down.  Choosing to shine, regardless of my angst completely blows their minds (and doesnt have me compromise my values). Boo to stinky work colleagues
Posts.Title: December 2011 Surgeries - want to wait together? CookieMonster Moonflwr912

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2013 04:37AM - edited Feb 15, 2013 04:38AM by KeepingFaith69 This diagnosis stinks! I don't want or like it, but it is what it is. I spent my first few days in fear and anxious, feeling angry and ripped off. It wasn't good for me and it was not good for my family. I have chosen to wake with a thankful heart, and make the most of every day. I spend time with the people I cherish and look to do things that make my heart sing. I choose to spend my remaining days (and I expect many years), LIVING with joy. I followed the advice if the lovely ladies on this forum and sought counselling. I also started mediation and art classes at the local hospice. All have helped me to navigate my fears. I am in a much better headspace, focused on living more than dying. I hope, Renae, that you too will find your way to a less anxious space. Sending you gentle hugs wrapped in peaceful joy and light. Pae xo

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2013 11:43PM KeepingFaith69 wrote: When in the treatment room, my heart went out to the ladies who didn't have a port. For me personally, I am glad that I have a port. I can only have needles in my left arm and my veins are difficult to find for bloods and scans. The thought of them having to prick me for chemo as well makes my tummy turn. It pokes out and sometimes I have to find creative ways to disguise the bump (depending on the cut if my dress), but I have no regrets.

Posts.Title: January 2012 rads Kate60 edoyrest

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2012 01:54AM KeepingFaith69 wrote: Hi, I was 40 when diagnosed on 2010 and turned 42 in December 2011. I was a D cup prior to having a mastectomy.  A mastectomy was recommended and I chose a bilateral (both came off). Getting through treatment was a priority for me and I chose to get a reconstruction 'later'. I was scheduled to discuss reconstruction options in November and had chosen to defer any extra surgery for another two years. After having a recurrence (November 2011) reconstruction is again not a priority for me. I wear foobs when I remember and have had to adjust my choice of dresses. I must admit that i really miss wearing strapless tops and tastfully low cut tops, but I manage. For me, living an extra day to see my husband and children is a highlight. One day I may have a reconstruction - but it is way down my list of priorities. I do miss my boobies sometimes.  However, I know that my boobs (although asthetically a positive) don't make me.  My beauty and attitude comes from within.  And although he misses them (he is a man after all), my husband loves me exactly as I am. I hope that helps : )
